results.title: Tosca
results.creator_credit: Brian Large, Sylvano Bussotti, Radiotelevisione Italiana and National Video Corporation
results.brief_description: Giacomo Puccini’s opera in three acts with libretto by Giuseppe Giacosa and Luigi Illica is based on the original play written for Sarah Bernhardt by the French playwright Victorien Sardou. “Tosca” is a dramatic love story involving the ill-fated painter Mario Cavaradossi (Giacomo Aragall), his love, the singer Floria Tosca (Eva Marton) and the evil Chief of Police, Baron Scarpia (Ingvar Wixell) and set in Rome in 1800. Performed live at the magnificent amphitheatre of Arena di Verona, this made for television production features the Orchestra and Chorus of the Arena di Verona with conductor Daniel Oren and Chorus master Tullio Boni, along with grand scale set designs and period costumes by Fiorenzo Giorgi. Sung in Italian with no English subtitles. Includes booklet with English translation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brian Large, Sylvano Bussotti, Radiotelevisione Italiana and National Video Corporation

results.title: Toronto Symphony No. 2
results.creator_credit: Julian Roffman, Alan Field and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The third movement of Tchaikovsky’s Sixth Symphony in B minor, played by the Toronto Symphony Orchestra under the direction of its conductor Sir Ernest McMillan. The camera picks out different sections of the orchestra, and some well-known musicians.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Julian Roffman, Alan Field and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Toronto Symphony No. 1
results.creator_credit: Julian Roffman, Alan Field and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The Toronto Symphony Orchestra is shown playing three contemporary works: “Jamaican Rhumba” by the Australian, Arthur Benjamin; Sir Ernest MacMillan’s “A St. Malo”, a sketch for strings; and, finally, the Overture to the opera, “Colas Breugnon” by Dimitri Kabalevskv.

results.title: Zoo Family. - Volume 2.
results.creator_credit: Chris Sheil, Howard Neil and Crawford Productions
results.brief_description: Zoo Family was filmed on location at the Melbourne Zoological Gardens and each adventure revolves around the zoo vet and his children, Susie and Nick who manage to get into all sorts of adventures. However it is the animals who are the real stars of the film.

results.title: The Trouble with medicine. [Part 2]
results.creator_credit: Stefan Moore, Martin Freeth, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and BBC
results.brief_description: Last three episodes of a major and controversial international series which looks at the challenges that face medical science today. “Disordered states” (Dir: Peter Montagnon): Explores mental illness and how the treatment of patients differs in different countries. India, Italy and the United States are shown as examples. “Pandemic” (Dir: Susan Lambert, Stefan Moore): Looks at AIDS programs in the USA where the high-tech approach to medicine is out of reach of most of those who need it, in Thailand, where the entire population is at threat, and in Australia where there has been some success in containing the disease. “Life support” (Dir: Henry Singer) The final episode looks at how modern medicine deals with the frail, elderly and the dying, exploring issues such as when is enough life support enough? Warning - some scenes in this video may disturb some viewers.

results.title: The Trouble with medicine. [Part 1]
results.creator_credit: Stefan Moore, Martin Freeth, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and BBC
results.brief_description: The first three episodes of a major and controversial international series which looks at the challenges that face medical science today. “Conceiving the future” (Dir: Tim Clark): Looks at genetics and the ethical dilemmas that arise from new technologies and being further able to pinpoint defects and abnormalities in unborn children. Asking questions such as what is abnormal? “Code of silence” (Dir: Stephen White): Examines to the heart of the doctor/patient relationship to find some extreme differences in the way physicians talk to their clients. “Temple of science” (Dir: Stefan Moore): Looks at the trend towards hi-tech medicine and specialisation, and Australia’s lead being the U.S.A. Warning: some scenes may be disturbing to some viewers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stefan Moore, Martin Freeth, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and BBC

Warning: some scenes may be disturbing to some viewers.

results.title: Warlords II for Mac
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. Four 3 1/2 inch floppy disks, registration card, subscription card, catalogue and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Warlords II refines on the formula that made the previous game so successful. New to the game is the addition of “fog of war”, where enemy units may be concealed from the map if a player’s own units are not close enough to see them. The interface and graphics have been upgraded and a suite of tools have been added to facilitate its multiplayer experience. This include a play by e-mail feature, a random map generator and a map editor.
results.description: Warlords II refines on the formula that made the previous game so successful. results.title: Aussie Rules Footy for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge sleeve and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Aussie Rules Footy was Beam Software’s first Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) sports game developed exclusively for the Australian market. Despite simple controls, its clever design captured the high-energy, competitive spirit of the sport, featuring spectacular high marking and pushing other players out from under a mark.

It also contained Beam’s signature sense of humour. Though voice samples were unusual in NES games of the era, Aussie Rules Footy used voice lines like the deadpan umpire’s “out of bounds on the full”, which complemented the droll text-based commentary between quarters.

Despite the official AFL logo on the box, it’s unlikely the game was licensed, which could be why the 18 playable teams don’t match their real-life counterparts, with curious inclusions like Darwin, Canberra and Hobart.

It also contained Beam’s signature sense of humour. Though voice samples were unusual in NES games of the era, Aussie Rules Footy used voice lines like the deadpan umpire’s “out of bounds on the full”, which complemented the droll text-based commentary between quarters.

Despite the official AFL logo on the box, it’s unlikely the game was licensed, which could be why the 18 playable teams don’t match their real-life counterparts, with curious inclusions like Darwin, Canberra and Hobart.

Aussie Rules Footy was Beam Software’s first Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) sports game developed exclusively for the Australian market. Despite simple controls, its clever design captured the high-energy, competitive spirit of the sport, featuring spectacular high marking and pushing other players out from under a mark.

It also contained Beam’s signature sense of humour. Though voice samples were unusual in NES games of the era, Aussie Rules Footy used voice lines like the deadpan umpire’s “out of bounds on the full”, which complemented the droll text-based commentary between quarters.

Despite the official AFL logo on the box, it’s unlikely the game was licensed, which could be why the 18 playable teams don’t match their real-life counterparts, with curious inclusions like Darwin, Canberra and Hobart.

results.title: The Trombonist
results.creator_credit: Wendy Campbell, Helen Gaynor and Gaynor Productions
results.brief_description: A day in the life of a muddle-minded trombone player. Cast includes Steve Kearney, Tracey Harvey, Ross Thompson, Earnie Bourne, John Thompson, Simon Thorpe, Tony Rickard, Helene Jacoby.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wendy Campbell, Helen Gaynor and Gaynor Productions
